ChecklistTitle: Did you establish a participatory planning group (PPG)?

Activity: Expertise and representation in the PPG
Description: NA

Activity: PPG contains expertise in the health problem and its causes
Description: Any indication that effort was invested to recruit one or more experts in the relevant health issue/problem/disease.
Scoring: Not reported (NA), reported as untrue without justification (1), reported as untrue and justified (2), reported as true (3)

Activity: Secure at least one target population member (or target population experts/proxy) in PPG
Description: Any indication that effort was invested to recruit one or more target population members
Scoring: Not reported (NA), reported as untrue without justification (1), reported as untrue and justified (2), reported as true (3)

Activity: PPG contains diverse perspectives from the target population
Description: Any indication that effort was invested to prevent the PPG from only containing people that are very positively indisposed towards the intervention (e.g. people who proactively offer their participation, such as very enthusiastic volunteers).
Scoring: Not reported (NA), reported as untrue without justification (1), reported as untrue and justified (2), reported as true (3)

Activity: Secure at least one prospective implementer in PPG (if applicable)
Description: Any indication that effort was invested to recruit one or more prospective implementers
Scoring: Not reported (NA), reported as untrue without justification (1), reported as untrue and justified (2), reported as true (3)

Activity: Secure at least one stakeholder in PPG (if applicable)
Description: Any indication that effort was invested to recruit one or more stakeholders. A stakeholder is defined as any individual or organisation that has one or more of power, legitimacy and urgency. Power is defines as formal authority or control. Legitimacy means that the stakeholder is acting in compliance with social norms and expectations. Urgency implies that the stakeholder calls for immediate attention.
Scoring: Not reported (NA), reported as untrue without justification (1), reported as untrue and justified (2), reported as true (3)

Activity: Change objectives are formulated according to the definition
Description: Each change objective concerns a specification of an aspect of a determinant of a performance objective. Change objectives are formulated as an action that, when exhibited by the target population, evidences the desired value of the sub-determinant (for example, using the action verbs from the IM book). In other words, change objectives are SMART goals that, when achieved, guarantee a relevant change in the corresponding determinant.
Scoring: Unclear or not reported (NA), all reported are incorrect (1), not all are available, or not all are correctly formulated (2), all are available and correct (3)

Description: A decision to evaluate this objective, and either the operationalisation, or a justification as to why this objective will not be evaluated.

Activity: Evaluation: select data provider for this operationalisation
Description: Indicate who provides the data for this operationalisation. For example, if the operationisation is a questionnaire measuring an environmental agents performance objectives, the questionnaire could be given to the environmental agents themselves (in which case they themselves would be the data provider), or to somebody in their environment, e.g. their manager, in which case that manager would be the data provider.
Select which methodology will be used; note that many operationalisations will normally be applied in the same methodology.

Any indication that the core processes were correctly applied. This can be coded either if correct use of core processes is explicitly claimed/stated, or if there are indications that all core processes (brainstorming, consulting the literature, using theory, and collecting additional data) were applied.
